climbs.name: Short, Sweet Crack
climbs.fa: unknown.  Someone must have done this before me!

content.description: This is a sweet hand and fist crack in a dihedral. It is only 15-20 feet, if that, above the boulders at the base. At the top, scramble across a gap and up to the top of Lover's Leap to the Beaver Brook trail.
content.protection: The crack itself could easily be protected with midsize cams.  An anchor could easily be constructed at the top of the crack.  I've only ever soloed it.  A fall from the crack would be "bad", but, with good crack technique, you can easily lock yourself into the crack.
content.location: Just to the left of the "BB" routes, scramble up a short boulder ramp to the base of this route. It is fantastic fun to run from Windy Saddle with a climbing shoe in each hand, change into shoes, jam the crack, scramble up to the trail, change back into running shoes, and run back, if you're so inclined!

content.description:
Previously route 'D' (unknown 11-) in the area description. I've finally gotten around to adding this to the database...

Follow the slabby boulder start to thuggish climbing through a bulge and up the main wall. Pull onto a ledge and shake out, taking a moment to consider the homework you should be doing before committing to the one-move crux. A few more thrutchy moves lead to easier ground and the anchor.
content.location:
Left of

Black and Blue

, start on a slabby boulder.

content.description: Start sitting matched on low jug. Go up and right, avoiding the tree, to the top. This has fun, steep moves on jugs.
content.location: This is an obvious line to the right of the trail, just before reaching the base of the BB climbs.

content.description: This is a project I just bolted.... it might require some time to send.... I wanted to open it up to anyone looking for a fight. This route is bouldery and cruxy. A stout, steep, thuggy V9 links to a 5.11 middle to a vertical, techy, desperate V9 crux at the end. The route still needs a bit of cleaning, but all of the heavy lifting is done.
content.location: This is the only route in the roof, just right of the main wall.

content.description:
This is a short climb that sort of begs to be climbed.  It pulls a tiny overlap with interesting moves that make it worth the dabble.

Move up to an obvious jug ~10 feet up.  Some nice footwork, an insecure lieback, and a chip get past the bulge.  Then, you get over your feet as the holds seem licheny.  Continue up on easier terrain until you get to the small roof above.  Traverse left to the anchors for

Bed and Breakfast

.

This may be a bit furry, since it was cleaned with bare hands and a nut tool.  Update, it's been cleaned gentle with a wire brush, now.

Given the aspect of the route, it'll likely need to be brushed every time it gets climbed.

If you set a TR above the roof, you could continue above.
content.protection:
A TR with swing potential off the anchors for

Bed and Breakfast

with a red Alien directional will keep you off the deck.  You might be tempted to put a couple cams in the angling crack to start, but it'll be a while until you can get anything in above that.  It would be a headpoint at best.
content.location:
This ascends the concavity ~perhaps 20 feet right of

Bed and Breakfast

.

content.description: Try not to hurt yourself in the kneebar that unlocks the start.  Attention to body positioning will keep you from getting beat up too badly and allow you to stand up into the cool sidepull underclings.  Careful footwork will keep the bruising down as you pull through the second crux to more amazing sidepulls.  A couple more moves and it's an easy cruise to the anchors.
content.location:
This is on the Northwest face, left of

Bed And Breakfast

.

content.description: Pull up on great jugs and traverse right to a clean, incipient crack in a bulge, load up (curved stopper, green Alien, RPs) and pull through to stand up and clip a bolt.  Continue up the slab above with good gear to the chains.
content.protection: Stoppers, small wires, Aliens, #0.5 through double 1 & 2 Camalots, one bolt, anchor bolts with chains.
content.location: This is on the Northwest face behind a large pine tree growing close to the wall.

climbs.name: BB King
climbs.fa: Kirk Miller, Ken Trout, Marsha Trout

content.description: This route offers fun face climbing in a great setting.
content.protection: 10 bolts to ring and chain anchors.
content.location: Start at the base and diagonal up and left to finish near the center of the top of the slab.

climbs.name: BB Gun
climbs.fa: Kirk Miller, Janice Sakata, BJ Nash

content.description: This is an engaging face climb with consistently thoughtful moves.
content.protection: 9 bolts to ring and chain anchors.

content.description: This is another great face climb with a fun mantle in the middle.
content.protection: 7 bolts to ring and chain anchors.
content.location:
This starts at the base, sharing its first bolt with

BB King

, then heads right and up, on the right side of the slab.

content.description:
This is an obvious line to the right of

Bed and Breakfast

that gains a hanging, soft, right-facing dihedral with some good holds and nice liebacks at times.  It is a bit furry still, since it was cleaned with a nut tool and bare hands.

Start about 5 feet to the right of

Bed and Breakfast

. There is a funky move low that might be tricky to do as a lead, since the 1st piece of gear is probably 15-18 feet up.  There is another interesting move about mid-route.  About 40 feet up, angle left to the anchors for

Bed and Breakfast

.

The climbing seems a bit better than

Bed And Breakfast

.
content.protection:
A TR with directional(s) of a red Alien and orange Alien makes it work.  For a lead, this would have limited options and would be likely R rated.

On lead, you can get a #0 TCU, yellow Alien (though, a hybrid green-yellow might be better), green Alien, small cam, red Alien, #1 Camalot, #0.5 Camalot, and a #0.75 Camalot.  Note, the gear is iffy until the small cam.
content.location:
This ascends the hanging, right-facing dihedral right of

Bed and Breakfast

.
